page.title: 18THE FISH HOUSE.
page.content: In 1922 my Granda started in Pattison- 's kipper house he was 15.He started at 6am and he finished at 10 or 11pm for 7 days a week and got Â£1.Three men and 14 girls worked there too.8am till 9 they went home for breakfast then worked right through till night. He had to wash big barrels of fish and fillet them ready to smoke,the herrin- gs were placed in troughs of pickle and left for half an hour to soak.Then they were hung up high above a kiln.A fire was made from oak chippings and sawdust and left until they smoked, then cured on racks.They used to do bloaters,herrings,smocked haddock.The fish were sent to Billingsgate Norway and Scotland and sold by a German auc- tioneer.Every box had to be stamped with the place that they were going to. Elizabeth Golden age 10
